Title: Trajectories of depression: Unobtrusive monitoring of depressive states by means of smartphone mobility traces analysis
Source: UbiComp - Proc. ACM Int. Jt. Conf. Pervasive Ubiquitous Comput.
Abstract: © ACM 978-1-4503-3574-4/15/09..15.00.One of the most interesting applications of mobile sensing is monitoring of individual behavior, especially in the area of mental health care. Most existing systems require an interaction with the device, for example they may require the user to input his/her mood state at regular intervals. In this paper we seek to answer whether mobile phones can be used to unobtrusively monitor individuals affected by depressive mood disorders by analyzing only their mobility patterns from GPS traces. In order to get ground-Truth measurements, we have developed a smartphone application that periodically collects the locations of the users and the answers to daily questionnaires that quantify their depressive mood. We demonstrate that there exists a significant correlation between mobility trace characteristics and the depressive moods. Finally, we present the design of models that are able to successfully predict changes in the depressive mood of individuals by analyzing their movements.
